abstract: A three-dimensional microporous Co-MOF with 5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin (DpyDtolP) linker exhibited high thermal stability. The original crystal structure was retained even after drying Co-MOF at 250 °C. The evacuated Co-MOF showed CO selectivity over N. Both CO-captured Co-MOF and I-captured Co-MOF were structurally characterized. The I-captured Co-MOF displayed conductivity implying the formation of polyiodine-based molecular wire inside MOF channels.A new porphyrin-based Co-MOF, [Co(DpyDtolP)]·12HO (), composed of DpyDtolP (5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin) was prepared in a high yield and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. DpyDtolP is a ditopic N-donor ligand with a large space or gap between the two pyridyl groups at the 5- and 15-positions of the porphyrin backbone. Unlike the pyridyl groups, the 4-tolyl groups in DpyDtolP could not be involved in coordination toward the metal ion. Nevertheless, the presence of these two 4-tolyl groups led to a new infinite three-dimensional framework: Co-MOF () with exceptionally high thermal stability at elevated temperature. The single crystals of  maintained their crystallinity even after vacuum drying at 250 °C. The resulting dried single crystals diffracted X-ray to give the same structural solution as the as-prepared crystals. The robust framework of  contained micropores that were periodically arranged in a hexagonal symmetry. While the evacuated  moderately sorbed N at 77 K, it sorbed 142.8 cm g (6.37 mmol g) of CO at 196 K. The CO sorption isotherms exhibited a very clear step in both the adsorption and desorption branches. A slight hysteretic behavior was observed between the two branches. Furthermore, the crystal structure of CO-captured  () revealed that the linear arrangement of the CO molecules occupied the inside of micropores, thereby indicating the effective CO capture by evacuated . The evacuated  was also found to be ideal for the encapsulation of iodine molecules in cyclohexane to provide iodine-captured  (), which was also characterized by X-ray crystallography. The linear arrangement of polyiodine chains in the micropores was observed, and a single crystal of  exhibited electrically conducting behavior. The encapsulation amount of iodine was dependent on the crystal sizes of . Additionally, the separately prepared microscale sample, , with a much reduced particle dimension than the bulk  exhibited an enhanced uptake of iodine under the same conditions.

10.1021/cg501324r Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesIntroductionPore engineering of porous materials has been a critical issue for generating new functional porous materials in a wide range of applications in materials chemistry.(1-6) For example, the selective capture of guest molecules or ions into well-defined open channels of porous materials often leads to sensitive sensing and capturing systems.(7-13) In this sense, crystalline zeolitic materials with well-defined framework structures display a unique molecular sieving effect, and in turn, this unique sieving effect makes it possible to develop new drying agents,(14) ion exchangers,(15) and industrial catalysts.(16-19) In order to expand the capabilities of natural zeolites, artificial zeolites have been sought for a long time. Because of the unique properties of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which include a high surface area,(20, 21) a controllable pore dimension,(22, 23) the functionality of the interior pore,(24-30) and the formation of new hybrid zeolitic, porous materials,(31-35) MOFs have become mainstream materials in the development of new functional inorganic crystalline porous materials. Applications have been advanced due to using MOFs. These applications include the large storage capacity of nonpolar CH4 and H2 gases;(36-40) the selective sorption of quadrupolar CO2 over N2, CH4, and H2;(41-54) the enzyme-mimetic asymmetric catalysis in confined space having a chiral active center;(55, 56) the heterogeneous catalysis inside catalytic cavities;(57-67) and the efficient proton conduction in functional pores.(68-73)Additionally, the nano- and microsized MOFs (nMOFs or mMOFs, respectively) have been reported frequently to have promising applications.(74, 75) In fact, they often demonstrate numerous advantages over both the MOFs and the inorganic nanomaterials.(76) Their novel and/or enhanced performances are reported in catalysis,(77) separation,(78) gas storage,(79) drug delivery,(80) biosensing, and imaging applications,(81) but the homogeneous fabrication of particles is still a major challenge.(82) Usually, a high temperature stirring method is employed in their construction because it permits the generation of quick ligand-to-metal coordinative interactions while maintaining the crystallinity and stability of these miniaturized MOFs.Very recently, the MOFs containing porphyrin-bridging ligands are attracting much interest due to their advantages over more commonly employed aromatic polycarboxylate-bridging ligands.(83-86) The porphyrin-based MOFs could be utilized for a wide range of advanced applications including selective catalysis,(87, 88) photosensitization,(89) and photovoltaics.(90) The large physical dimensions of the porphyrin unit can also lead to high surface functional MOFs with enhanced hydrolytic stability. In this sense, Yaghi and co-workers recently reported on water-stable Zr(IV)-based Zr6O4(OH)4(H2TCPP)3 (MOF-525) and Zr6O8(H2O)8(H2TCPP)2 (MOF-545), which contain free-base tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (H2TCPP)-bridging ligands.(91) The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-525 and MOF-545 reached 2620 and 2260 m2 g–1, respectively. Zhou and co-workers also reported on the water/pH tolerant, (Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(OH)4(H2O)4(H2TCPP)2) Zr-TCPP-functional MOF (PCN-225).(92) The PCN-225 displayed an interesting pH-dependent fluorescence in an aqueous medium. Combined with the intrinsic stability of Zr(IV)-based MOFs, these two examples opened up a new class of functional porphyrin-MOFs.Moreover, the molecular dimension and functionalities of porphyrin-bridging ligands could be systematically varied in a controllable manner through the simple modification of functional groups at the meso-position of the porphyrin backbone on demand. Matsunaga and co-workers prepared a Zn-TCPEP MOF where TCPEP is 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxymethylphenyl)ethynyl-porphyrin.(93) H2TCPEP had extended substituents at the meso-position of the porphyrin.(93)The flat geometry of the porphyrin backbone with various substituents at the meso-positions was found to be ideal for the construction of MOFs with a wide range of applications. Therefore, we discuss herein the preparation of thermally robust porphyrin-MOF and their microsized crystalline particles with hexagonal pore symmetry from pyridine-substituted porphyrin, 5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin (DpyDtolP), and their selective uptake of CO2 over N2. Particularly, we thoroughly examined the CO2-containing single crystals of the MOFs in order to investigate the solid-state structures of the CO2 molecules captured inside the MOF channels. We did so because the single crystal structures with captured molecules would provide new and important information for the development of better sorbent materials that would otherwise be difficult to obtain. Furthermore, the structural analysis of the MOFs with captured polyiodine chains was investigated.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesExperimental SectionInstrumentationNuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Varian AS400 (399.937 MHz for 1H and 100.573 MHz for 13C) spectrometer. The 1H chemical shifts are referenced to the proton resonance resulting from the protic residue in deuterated solvent, and the 13C chemical shift recorded downfield in ppm relative to the carbon resonance of the deuterated solvents. The absorbance and emission spectra were obtained using an Agilent UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer using quartz cells. All scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JSM-7001F. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was obtained using a Horiba EMAX Gatan at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI) Seoul Center. The yield was 0.044 g (60%). The single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were directly chosen from the as-prepared crystals. Anal. The CCD data were integrated and scaled using the Bruker-SAINT software package. The structures were solved and refined using the SHEXTL V6.12 program.(94) For the structure of I_CO2_195 K containing CO2 molecules, the occupancies of CO2 have been fixed in order to obtain the best fit with the largest residual peaks. For the structure of I_I2, the occupancies of I atoms have also been fixed in order to obtain the best fit with the largest residual peaks. All hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated positions. The device performance was evaluated in air using a 4200-SCS semiconductor characterization system under ambient conditions, and the averages of the extracted values were obtained from a total of ten devices measured.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesResults and DiscussionThe ligand, 5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin (DpyDtolP), has the porphyrin core bearing two pyridyl groups at the 5- and 15-positions and two 4-tolyl groups at the 10- and 20-positions. The metalation of DpyDtolP with Co(NO3)2·6H2O created a new three-dimensional (3-D) porphyrin-based MOF, [Co(DpyDtolP)]6·12H2O (I). The porphyrin-MOF, I, was obtained at 120 °C in DMF with 48 h of reaction time. This new 3-D porphyrin-MOF, I, possesses a hexagonally arranged micropore network as shown in Figure 1a and described in Table 1; the structures of I along a- and b-axes were shown in Figure S1, Supporting Information. The dimensions of the hexagonal channels were estimated as shown in Figure S2, Supporting Information. Four pyrrolic nitrogen atoms coordinate a metal ion, and both pyridyl nitrogen atoms also coordinate the neighboring metal ions to form a 3-D hexagonal network. The coordination around each metal ion is a distorted octahedral structure constructed by six N atoms with four pyrrole groups in a plane and two pyridyls at the apical positions (Figure 1b and Table 2). In fact, two coordinated pyridyls are tilted from the N4 porphyrin ring with the tilting angles of 71.09(8)° for I (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Water molecules are present in the voids, but they could not be refined due to disordering problem. The total number of electrons for the disordered water molecules can be counted by using PLATON SQUEEZE, and the estimated number of water molecules can support the presence of certain water guests in the pore.Figure 1. (a) Structure of a solvent-free, 3-D [Co(DpyDtolP)]6 (I) indicating hexagonally arranged micropores. (b) Coordination geometry around a CoII ion in a crystallographic inversion center. Displacement ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry operations: (i) 1 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; (ii) −1/3 – x + y, 1 + 1/3 – x, 1/3 + z; and (iii) 1 + 1/3 – y, 1 + 2/3 + x – y, −1/3 + z. (c) The Connolly surface of the solvent-free I along the c-axis probed with a probe radius of 1.4 Å. Gray color indicates the external surfaces, whereas the orange color indicates the internal surfaces. Two distinct pores are indicated at spots “A” and “B”.I crystallized in the trigonal space group R3̅. The dimensions of a hexagonal channel without the 4-tolyl group can be anticipated as a/2 × a/√3 (16.32 × 18.85 Å), but the actual dimensions are smaller due to the 4-tolyl groups (Figure S2, Supporting Information). The actual free radius is about 8.13 Å, which is estimated by measuring the distance between the channel center to one of the methyl C atoms in the six −CH3 groups forming a hexamer and subtracting the van der Waals radius of C, 1.7 Å. On the basis of the PLATON analysis, the solvent-free I indicated a 16.4% of void volume.(95) It is noted that the orientation of the hexagonally arranged, one-dimension (1-D)-like micropores are parallel to the c-axis of the real crystal based on the face-indexing result (Figure 2). Thus, the single crystal of I could be regarded as a crystalline bundle of inorganic–organic hybrid nanotubes with permanent microporosity. As discussed further in a later section, each 1-D channel is radially interconnected each other.Figure 2. Face-indexing result of a real crystal I and the corresponding orientation of the unit cell. Arrow indicates the micropore orientation along the c-axis.As depicted in Figure 3, the as-prepared I contains two solvated water molecules per Co(DpyDtolP) unit as based on the elemental analysis and the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). These two water molecules could be completely removed at 500 °C under ambient conditions. It is presumed that the small weight loss near 500 °C may be due to the removal of the −CH3 groups (−4.3%). Notably, the single crystallinity of the framework of I was still retained even after the loss of water molecules upon heating the sample at 250 °C under high vacuum for 2 h (Table 1). The actual shape of the open spaces in the solvent-free I was evaluated by generating the Connolly surface as depicted in Figure 1c. The evacuated I contains very well-defined 1-D open channels along the c-axis. Interestingly, each 1-D channel is interconnected with other channels. Hence, two open spaces are marked as spots “A” and “B” in Figure 1c.Figure 3. TG profiles of the as-prepared I (black), micro-I (red), and micro-II (blue) under N2 atmosphere.When this robust empty framework was exposed to CO2 gas at 195 K, the CO2 molecules were captured in crystallographic −3 axes (Figure 4). The crystal structure of the I_CO2_195 K was obtained at 170 K. The occupancies of the CO2 have been fixed in order to obtain the best fit with the largest residual peaks (Table 1), but the actual occupancies at 195 K should be larger than the fixed occupancies since the uptake amount measured at 196 K reached up to 142.8 cm3 g–1 (6.37 mmol g–1). Very few examples for the solid-state structures of the CO2 molecules captured inside the MOF were very recently reported.(96-98) The single crystal structures of the captured CO2 molecules provide valuable information for the development of better sorbent materials that would otherwise be difficult to obtain. Shimizu and co-workers first reported on the crystal structure for the CO2 molecules bound in the amine-functionalized MOF, Zn2(Atz)2(ox) where Atz is 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and ox is oxalate.(96) In I_CO2_195 K, we could only observe the CO2 molecules partially captured in channel “A”. In our system, the interaction between the framework of I and the CO2 molecules might not be as strong as in Zn2(Atz)2(ox) due to the absence of Lewis base sites.Figure 4. Structure of I_CO2_195 K along the c-axis (a) and b-axis (b). All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.Stimulated by the successful determination of CO2 captured single crystal structure of I, the gas sorption capacities of the evacuated I were evaluated further in detail by a standard volumetric sorption analysis for N2, CO2, H2, and CH4 at suitable temperatures. The evacuated I sorbed a small uptake amount of N2 at 77 K as depicted in Figure 5, and it only sorbed 87.8 cm3 g–1 of N2. Nevertheless, the isotherm shape is type-I, which is a typical indication of microporosity. The BET surface area was 280 m2 g–1 with a total pore volume of 0.14 cm3 g–1. The low uptake could be mainly attributed to the small pore dimension of I due to the pore blocking effect of the bulky 4-tolyl moieties as well as relatively low adsorptivty of the N2 gas.Figure 5. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for solvent-free I (a) and micro-I (b) at 77 K.However, as shown in Figure 6a, the Co-MOF I exhibited a large uptake of CO2 at 196 K. The enhanced uptake of CO2 over N2 could be attributed to the smaller kinetic diameters of CO2 (3.30 Å) than N2 (3.64 Å).(43) Moreover, CO2 is known to have better adsorptivity on the surfaces over N2 because of its higher quadrupole moment (43.0 × 10–27 esu–1 cm–1 for CO2 vs 15.2 × 10–27 esu–1 cm–1 for N2).(43) The low-pressure uptake amount measured at 196 K for I reached up to 142.8 cm3 g–1 (6.37 mmol g–1). Notably, a very clear adsorption step around P = 0.4 atm occurred. The adsorption step in an S-shape isotherm is usually attributed to one of the two factors: (1) the framework flexibility during adsorption(99, 100) or (2) the electronic attraction of preadsorbed CO2 molecules with newly incoming CO2 molecules.(101) Because the robustness of the framework of the evacuated I was empirically demonstrated by the X-ray diffraction study, the origin of the step could be attributed to the latter. Nevertheless, another possibility in our system is that the adsorption step resulted from the presence of two distinct micropores in I. Even though we could not directly observe the CO2 molecules occupied in pore “B” in the I_CO2_195 K structure, pore “A” could be filled first, and then pore “B” could be accessed by the CO2 molecules upon increasing the CO2 pressure. The desorption isotherm also displayed a very similar pattern compared with the adsorption isotherm. The location of the desorption step was virtually identical with that of the adsorption process. Very slight hysteretic behavior between the adsorption and desorption branches occurred. Interestingly, however, I displayed almost no adsorption of CO2 at 273 K. The amount of CO2 sorption at 273 K was very small: 9.0 cm3 g–1 (0.40 mmol g–1).Figure 6. CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for solvent-free I (a) and micro-I (b).Both gas sorption analyses for CH4 at 196 K and H2 at 77 K indicated low levels of uptake compared with the value for CO2 at 196 K (Figure S4, Supporting Information): CH4, 24.7 cm3 g–1 (1.10 mmol g–1); H2, 53.7 cm3 g–1 (2.39 mmol g–1). Despite the low levels of adsorption for the two gases, the adsorption of the smaller H2 gas is more favorable than the large CH4 gas.Encouraged by the excellent thermal stability of Co-MOF I, we performed the high temperature stirring method in order to obtain analogous microparticles of Co-MOF I within a short reaction time. Vigorous stirring of a solution composed of DpyDtolP and Co(NO3)2·6H2O in anhydrous DMF at 120 °C gave microsized crystalline needles (micro-I and micro-II). The diameters of the needles were modulated systematically from ∼500 nm to ∼1 μm in thickness by varying the reaction time from 45 to 120 min (Figure S5, Supporting Information).Remarkably, these microsized crystalline needles (micro-I and micro-II) with various lengths exhibited the same PXRD patterns as the bulk single-crystalline Co-MOF I, thus confirming that they are indeed isostructural in spite of their distinct fabrication methods (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Regardless of their particle dimensions, the TGAs of micro-I and micro-II showed the same profiles for the dehydration step as I (Figure 3). The curves show an initial weight loss due to the solvent liberation around 500 °C and the decomposition of the frameworks above 750 °C. These results demonstrate the excellent thermal stability of the frameworks despite the microsized nature of both micro-I and micro-II. I indicated slower weight loss after 500 °C than both micro-I and micro-II, and this result can be attributed to the fact that smaller microsized MOFs can be thermally less stable at elevated temperature.The gas sorption capacities of the evacuated micro-I were also investigated for N2, CO2, H2, and CH4 at suitable temperatures. The evacuated micro-I sorbed a very similar amount of N2 at 77 K as compared to bulk I and showed a typical type-I isotherm (Figure 5b). The sample exhibited a slightly lower BET surface area (260 m2 g–1) than that of the bulk I, but the total pore volume of 0.60 cm3 g–1 was 4-fold larger than that of the bulk I. This result could be ascribed to the presence of the large interparticle voids for micro-I, and these voids can be observed as a dramatic increase of an adsorbed amount of N2 above P/P0 = 0.9 atm. The low uptake ability can be mainly attributed to the small pore dimension of micro-I. This is due to the pore blocking effect of the bulky 4-tolyl moieties and the low adsorptivity of N2 gas as mentioned earlier for the bulk I. However, the evacuated micro-I showed a relatively large amount of CO2 uptake at 196 K but no adsorption of CO2 at 273 K. These behaviors were very similar to those of the bulk Co-MOF I (Figure 6). The CO2 uptake amount measured at 196 K, 125.6 cm2 g–1 (5.60 mmol g–1), is comparable to that of I. Even the shapes of the adsorption–desorption isotherms are very similar to that of bulk sample of I. Interestingly, both bulk I and micro-I exhibited a much enhanced adsorption for CO2 than N2. The gas sorption analyses for CH4 at 196 K and H2 at 77 K indicated low levels of uptake (Figure S4, Supporting Information): CH4, 20.8 cm3 g–1 (0.93 mmol g–1); H2, 36.6 cm3 g–1 (1.63 mmol g–1).The capture of iodine inside the MOF channels is an attractive method for stabilizing the volatile and potentially toxic iodine.(102-108) Interestingly, when the robust solvent-free framework I was immersed into a solution of iodine in cyclohexane, its hexagonally arranged channels allowed iodine to form very intriguing polyiodine chains. The iodine-captured framework of I, I_I2, was structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography (Table 1). The iodine atoms occupied the crystallographic −3 axes (Figure 7). The iodine–iodine distance is 3.064 Å, and the middle iodine atom has an inversion center generating I3– ion, and the distance between I3– is 3.212 Å (Figure 7c). Notably, the distance of I3–···I3– in the channel is relatively short compared with the previously reported values for an infinite I3– chain of 4.0–4.2 Å found in [H3O(dibenzo-18-crown-6)][I3].(109) Therefore, the polyiodine instead of discrete I3– ions adopts a symmetric structure in I_I2. In contrast, the iodine–iodine distance is much elongated compared with the value found in I2@ZIF-8 (2.769 Å).(102) This unusual structure for the captured polyiodines in the channels is manifested by the unique pore geometry of I. I2 encapsulation kinetics for the bulk I and micro-I in cyclohexane.Top of PageAbstractIntroductionExperimental SectionResults and DiscussionConclusionsReferencesConclusionsWe prepared very robust, thermally stable porphyrin-based 3-D Co-MOF, [Co(DpyDtolP)]6·12H2O (I), which gave good refined diffraction data for the single crystal structure analysis after drying at 250 °C. The original crystal structure did not change even after heat treatment at 250 °C. Permanently microporous Co-MOF I contained well-defined, radially interconnected, and hexagonally oriented 1-D channels. The evacuated I exhibited a high uptake of CO2 at 196 K, and the CO2-captured single crystal structure was successfully solved. The uptake amount of CO2 at 196 K was higher than that of N2 at 77 K. The microscale analogue of I, micro-I, also displayed very similar sorption isotherms and uptake amounts for CO2 and N2 under the same conditions. The micro-I showed faster kinetics for encapsulating I2 in cyclohexane. The crystal structure of the iodine-captured I, I_I2, was also refined, and the unique polyiodine chains in 1-D MOF channels were unequivocally confirmed. Both the XPS and Raman spectroscopic analyses indicated that the polyiodine chains contained several types of iodine species. As evidenced from high electrical conductivities, the 1-D polyiodine chains in the micropores behaved as molecular wires. As evidenced from I–V characteristics, the electrically conducting properties of polyiodine chains were preserved. We envision that the functionalities in the 1-D micropores of I could be further fine-tuned by introducing different functional groups at the position of the 4-tolyl groups for further advanced applications.
